intro: Melothria longituba, commonly known as the long-stemmed globemallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and is characterized by its showy, five-petaled flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in arid or semi-arid environments. Its leaves are palmately lobed, and it produces small, round fruits that contain several seeds. Melothria longituba is often found in desert scrub and chaparral habitats, where it plays a role in supporting local pollinators.
